question: The percentage of correct predictions within a model.
Intelligence that can be programmed to mimic human intelligence.
A set of rules used to generate calculations or perform problem-solving operations.
An unusual activity in a group of otherwise normal activities.
The parts of data or a system that are vulnerable to attack.
A model's probability of choosing a positive instance over a negative instance.
An imbalance in data that can cause data to be skewed toward a demographic group, which can harm an AI machine-learning model.
A model type in which a result is categorized, usually with one of two values, such as a yes or no value.
Data stored on an on-premises or cloud storage drive.
Data in the process of being copied or moved from one location to another.
The harmonic mean of precision and recall.
An input to an AI model used to generate output.
Data that is paired with output targets in an AI model.
A form of regression in which an outcome is a continuous variable, like a number.
A form of regression in which an outcome uses binary dependent variables.
An app used to generate predictions and outcomes based on the entering and training of data entered into the app.
A form of AI that reads data from text and images and can include speech recognition and object detection.
The percentage of true positive predictions among all positive predictions in an outcome.
A permission standard in which permissions are assigned to roles, and roles are assigned to individuals and groups.
The measure of true positive predictions among all actual positives.
A model type that looks at the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables.
A type of machine learning model in which an AI agent performs actions that maximize a certain reward.
A document that contains known risks for a project and the impact, probability, and mitigation strategy for those risks.
The plot of the True Positive Rate against the False Positive Rate for model results.
A value that measures the proportion of variance of a dependent variable that is predictable from independent variables.
The ability to adjust machine resources up or down depending upon workload demand.
An expert on the problem or problems attempting to be solved through the use of an AI model.
In the context of AI, the act of being forthright about how data is collected and used for AI models.
Data that is not paired with output targets in an AI model.
A type of machine learning model that looks for hidden patterns or structures in data.
A belief or condition taken to be true for a system to work as intended.
A cloud-based tool used to build AI models.
A form of data that stores information as ones and zeros.
A limitation or restriction on an AI system.
A measure of connection between two points of data.
A characteristic of data, such as numeric, string, or date.
A feature built using a formula, through splitting or combining data, or by assigning keywords based on conditions.
An ordered list of numerical properties of observed phenomena.
A form of encoding that assigns categorical variables to binary numbers.
A tool used to cleanse data to ready it for an AI learning model.
A Microsoft tool used to build chatbots.
A logical statement or condition defining properties or relationships between entities in an AI system.
A form of machine learning in which data is assigned a positivity or negativity value.
The ratio of data used for training an AI model versus the data used for testing.
The process of converting words to numbers to be used for data in an AI model.
A tool used to cleanse data to ready it for an AI learning model.
A chart that defines true/false positives and true/false negatives for an AI model.
A machine learning method in which samples are split into sets based on input variable differentiators.
An algorithm used for neural networks that support human-like AI interactions.
A clear explanation for a decision, prediction, or recommendation made by an AI model.
An incorrect negative result for an AI model.
An incorrect positive result for an AI model.
The European Union standard for data handling that affects companies doing business in the EU.
A dataset that has too much data from one or more groups.
The ability to understand the results of an AI model.
A repeated sequence of training cycles for an AI model.
A machine learning model that splits data into an unspecified number of groups.
A visualization that sets standards for performance for AI models.
A type of algorithm designed to mimic the human brain.
A situation in which a model learns training data too well but performs poorly on new data.
An input value used to help train an algorithm.
Data gathered on an AI model to ensure proper function.
A phenomenon where biased data perpetuates existing biases in an AI model.
The relative change of a model and its output.
The evaluation of a model's ability to accurately identify negative instances.
An individual or group that may affect or be affected by a project.
An algorithm that uses labeled data.
A pattern of data within an AI model.
A correct negative result for an AI model.
A correct positive result for an AI model.
A situation in which a model performs poorly on both training and new data.
An algorithm that does not use labeled data.
A chart or report that explains the results of an AI model or its data.
A test where data is intentionally manipulated to evaluate vulnerability to adversarial attacks.
A set of rules that allows applications to communicate with each other.
The change in underlying concepts used to train AI models.
The change in statistical properties of input data in an AI model.
A mechanism that identifies shifts in underlying data.
Testing an AI system's performance beyond normal operating ranges.
A means of collecting feedback for an AI system.
A repository used to store code for development projects.
A file format in which data is stored in key-value pairs.
A series of steps used to transform data into a final AI model prediction.
Microsoft's database server used to store data for AI pipelines.
The willingness of people to use an AI model and its outputs.
A test in which different app versions are shown to different people and usage patterns are compared.
The act of no longer using an AI model in production.
A mode in which an AI model is not performing at maximum capability.
A list of activities in an AI model that may indicate potential security issues.
The extent to which people use an AI model to its fullest.
